title: 114_hr3442
content: The Act titled "Debt Management and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2015" requires the Secretary of the Treasury to report to Congress before reaching the debt limit. The "Debt Management and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2015" mandates the Secretary of the Treasury to report to Congress 60-21 days before the public debt reaches the specified limit. The report must include historical debt levels and current status. The Secretary of the Treasury must report to Congress on the debt, including historical levels, current amount, future projections, revenue levels, drivers of future debt, and measures to fund obligations if the debt limit is not raised. The Secretary of the Treasury must report to Congress on the debt levels, projections, revenue, and measures to fund obligations if the debt limit is not raised. Congress must be notified when the Secretary starts implementing measures to address the debt, and the President may recommend a balanced budget amendment to control future debt accumulation. The President's proposals to reduce public debt in the short, medium, and long term must be explained in detail. The curr_chunk discusses the impact of increasing the debt limit on government spending, debt service, and the position of the US dollar as the international reserve currency. It also includes projections on the fiscal health of major entitlement programs like Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid. Additionally, it mentions the President's plan to publicly disclose reduction measures if the debt limit is reached. The curr_chunk provides details on reduction measures used by the Secretary to avoid defaulting on government obligations, including the total dollar amount used and estimated remaining amount for each measure. It also includes the estimated date when all reduction measures will be exhausted, leading to government default. The curr_chunk outlines the Secretary's extraordinary measures to fund government obligations if the debt limit is not raised, including projections on how long these measures will last and the associated administrative costs. It also questions the Administration's ability to prioritize paying only principal and interest on the national debt if the debt limit is reached. The Secretary of the Treasury will provide public access to information on the Department of the Treasury's website, including the debt report, detailed explanation, and progress report submitted under subsection (b). This access will be available for at least 6 months after the information is released. The Secretary of the Treasury will provide public access to information on the Department of the Treasury's website, including the debt report, detailed explanation, progress report, and other necessary information related to the statutory debt limit and Government debt. Reduction measures are defined as directing debt issuance, suspending investments in the Government Securities Investment Fund, and suspending investments in the stabilization fund. The Secretary of the Treasury may take various measures to address the statutory debt limit, including suspending investments in certain funds, selling assets before maturity, and other appropriate actions. The House of Representatives passed a report on reaching the debt limit on February 11, 2016.
